bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Gary G. Sick was responsible for programs relating to foreign policy at the Ford Foundation from 1982-1987. Prior to joining the Foundation, he served in the U.S. government as a naval captain and in policy positions in the National Security Council and the Department of Defense. During his five years at the National Security Council, he served Presidents Ford, Carter, and Reagan on issues related to the Middle East. He was the principal White House aide for Iranian affairs during the Iranian Revolution and subsequent hostage crisis. From 1973-1976 he served in the Office of the Assistant Secretary of Defense (International Security Affairs), with special responsibility for security policy involving the Persian Gulf and Indian Ocean areas. Dr. Sick holds a Ph.D. degree from in political science from Columbia University, and his professional experience includes posts in the Persian Gulf, Morocco, Italy, and Egypt. He received his undergraduate degree in French literature from Kansas University where he was the recipient of Fulbright and Rotary fellowships for graduate studies in France. Dr. Sick is the executive director of the Gulf/2000 Project at Columbia University (1993â€“present), which has published five books and numbers many of the leading scholars on the Persian Gulf among its global membership. He is an adjunct professor of International Affairs and a senior research scholar at Columbia's School of International and Public Affairs. He is emeritus member of the board of directors of Human Rights Watch, and serves as founding chair of the Advisory Committee of Human Rights Watch/Middle East.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of Dr. Gary Sick's correspondence with grantees regarding ongoing grants, grant rejection and acceptance letters, and requests for further information on proposed projects. The collection also contains Dr. Sick's inter-office memos with Ford Foundation International Affairs program staff regarding grantmaking decisions, Recommended Grant Action forms (RGAs), trip and conference summaries, Dr. Sick's publications, and discussions of how to evenly allocate funding to underserved areas of study.
